title: Emergence, Life and Consciousness and the Roadblock of Semantics
description:
Karl, who studied physics at U. C. Berkeley and Glen, who studied physics at U. C. Santa Cruz, debate whether it is possible to describe emergence with a mathematical formalism. Their differences sometimes come down to a matter of semantics, particularly the meaning of choice, as they debate the two clearest examples of strong emergence:  life and consciousness.

Video defining strong and weak emergence:  https://youtu.be/66p9qlpnzzY

Paul describes his God #1 and God #2 starting at 6:28 in this video. I cued it up so hopefully, it will start there:  https://youtu.be/o1PBecOQWAk?t=388

The theory on the origin of life that I referenced from Dr. Eric Smith at the McCloskey lecture series:  https://youtu.be/0cwvj0XBKlE

Glen's argument is partially based on the concept that Life is radically different from an inert system, for Life will seek out and go to where energy differentials exist and tries to equalize them. Glen refers to this as "choice". 
Karl rejects the use of the word "choice" in this instance, for to him, choice can only exist where there is consciousness. Therefore, a bacteria does not have "choice". The fundamental that underlies this disagreement is whether or not there is intelligence behind the emergence of Life. Listen in on these two thinkers as they tackle this complex topic.
